questions.text: A 5-year-old child presented with fever, red eye and sore throat. He had participated in a summer camp organized by his school, a few days ago, after which other kids also presented with similar complaints. Which of the following viruses is most likely to be the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The most likely causative agent causing fever, red eye, and sore throat in a child after a camp suggestive of pharyngoconjunctival fever is adenovirus.
  • Adenoviruses are DNA viruses responsible for diseases involving the respiratory, gastrointestinal, and urinary tracts, as well as the eye.
  • They are non-enveloped, icosahedral in shape, with a genome composed of linear double-stranded DNA. Adenoviruses have unique structural features such as fibers protruding from each of the 12 vertices (penton bases) as shown below, contributing to their attachment and internalization into host cells.
  • Human adenoviruses are classified under the Mastadenovirus genus, with 57 distinct serotypes divided into seven groups (A-G).
  • These groups differ in their GC content of their DNA, hemagglutination patterns, and oncogenic potential.
  • About one-third of human adenovirus serotypes are known to cause human disease. Serotypes 1-7 account for most cases worldwide. 
  • Adenovirus infection can lead to acute hemorrhagic cystitis in both children and individuals who have undergone renal or bone marrow transplantation.
  • Detection includes virus isolation, PCR, antigen testing, and electron microscopy. Group-specific antibodies are not serotype-specific and do not confirm past infections.
  • There is no specific treatment. Preventive measures include hygiene, chlorination of swimming pools, and sterilization during eye exams.

Explanation of other options:

Parvovirus (Option A): Parvovirus B19 infection commonly presents in children as erythema infectiosum, characterized by fever and a "slapped cheek" facial rash, sometimes accompanied by joint symptoms in adults. It can also cause transient aplastic crisis in individuals with chronic hemolytic anemia and persistent severe anemia in immunocompromised patients, such as those with congenital immunodeficiency or post-transplantation.

EBV (Option B): In children, primary EBV infections are usually asymptomatic, whereas adolescents and young adults commonly develop infectious mononucleosis. This condition typically presents after an incubation period of 30–50 days with symptoms such as headache, fever, fatigue, sore throat, splenomegaly and lymphadenopathy.

Measles (Option D): Measles typically presents with a prodrome of fever, cough, coryza, conjunctivitis with photophobia, and Koplik spots, followed by a descending light pink maculopapular rash that progresses to brownish blotches and resolves with desquamation

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy presented with mild fever, lethargy and flu-like symptoms for the past few days. He is a known case of sickle cell anemia.. His laboratory parameters are as follows:
Hb: 5.3 g/dL
RBC count: 3.5 million/microliter (Normal- 4.2 to 6.1 million)
WBC count- 6500/cubic mm
Platelets count- 1,70,000/cubic mm
Which of the following organisms might be responsible?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario of anemia in a child with sickle cell anemia is suggestive of aplastic crises caused by parvovirus.
  • Parvoviruses are among the smallest DNA viruses with nonenveloped icosahedral capsids and a single-stranded DNA genome.
  • They rely on host cell machinery for replication due to their limited coding capacity and primarily infect dividing cells.
  • Human parvovirus B19, the most clinically significant member of the Parvovirinae subfamily, shows a distinct tropism for erythroid progenitor cells.
  • Its replication depends on the presence of blood group P antigen and α5β1 integrin on host cells, and it typically occurs in the nucleus, utilizing host cell DNA polymerases.
  • B19 is responsible for several human diseases. In children, it causes erythema infectiosum or "fifth disease," which presents as a flu-like illness followed by a characteristic "slapped cheek" rash and may include joint symptoms, especially in adults.
  • In individuals with underlying hemolytic disorders such as sickle cell disease or thalassemia, it can trigger a transient aplastic crisis marked by abrupt cessation of red cell production and worsening anemia.
  • Immunocompromised individuals may develop pure red cell aplasia, a chronic condition characterized by severe anemia due to persistent infection.
  • In pregnant women, B19 infection can be transmitted vertically and may result in fetal anemia or hydrops fetalis, particularly when infection occurs before the 20th week of gestation.
  • B19 virus is environmentally stable and can be transmitted via respiratory droplets, blood products, or from mother to fetus.
  • Diagnosis is primarily molecular, using PCR to detect viral DNA in blood, respiratory secretions, or tissue samples, and serology to assess for IgM (indicative of recent infection) and IgG (indicative of past exposure).
  • Treatment is generally supportive, with transfusion support for severe anemia and intravenous immunoglobulin therapy for chronic infections in immunocompromised hosts.

Explanation of other options:

Salmonella typhi (Option A): Salmonella infections can manifest as enteric fever, septicemia, or enterocolitis, each with distinct clinical patterns. Enteric fever presents with a gradual onset, prolonged high fever, and early constipation followed by bloody diarrhea. Septicemia typically has an abrupt onset with high spiking fever but minimal gastrointestinal symptoms. Enterocolitis, in contrast, begins abruptly with nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea within 8-48 hours and has a short duration. Patients, specifically children, with sickle cell disease or sickle cell trait are exceedingly more susceptible to Salmonella infections and particularly to Salmonella bacteremia and its complications such as osteomyelitis when compared to people with normal hemoglobin.

Haemophilus influenza (Option B): Individuals with sickle cell disease face heightened vulnerability to infections caused by encapsulated bacteria, largely due to impaired splenic function.Additionally, abnormalities in the alternative complement pathway contribute to poor bacterial opsonization. As a result, infections such as septicemia and meningitis caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae and Haemophilus influenzae are frequently observed but It does not lead to worsening anemia

Streptococcus pneumoniae (Option D): Patients with sickle cell anemia are at increased risk of pneumococcal infections but it does not lead to aplastic crisis.

questions.text: A 29-year-old retropositive truck driver presented to Dermatology OPD with an itchy rash growing on his torso, which is shown below. On examination, his temperature was 100.4Â°F and BP was 120/80 along with generalized lymphadenopathy. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given clinical vignette of raised reddish lesions in a retropositive patient is suggestive of Kaposi sarcoma caused by human herpes virus-8.
  • Human Herpesvirus 8 (HHV-8), also known as Kaposi sarcoma–associated herpesvirus (KSHV), is a lymphotropic virus closely related to Epstein–Barr virus and herpesvirus saimiri.
  • The KSHV genome contains genes that affect cellular processes such as proliferation, apoptosis, and immune responses, suggesting that the virus contributes to tumor formation through manipulation of host cell regulatory mechanisms.
  • KSHV transmission primarily occurs via oral secretions but can also be spread through sexual contact, blood transfusion, vertical transmission, and organ transplantation. Infections are highly prevalent in Africa, often beginning in early childhood.
  • Kaposi sarcoma (KS), a vascular tumor of mixed cellular composition, is the most frequent neoplasm in AIDS patients, though it is rare in immunocompetent individuals.
  • Kaposi sarcoma lesions comprise proliferating spindle cells derived from endothelial and smooth muscle cells, forming slit-like vascular spaces and showing inflammatory infiltrates.
  • Spindle cells in KS produce inflammatory and angiogenic mediators that promote tumor growth and vascularization.
  • HHV-8 infection plays a central role in KS pathogenesis, but additional cofactors, especially HIV-induced immunosuppression, are needed for disease expression.
  • The virus has also been implicated in other AIDS-related tumors like B-cell lymphomas such as primary effusion lymphoma and also multicentric Castleman disease.
  • Diagnostic approaches include PCR and serologic assays, as direct culture is impractical.
  • Antiviral drugs such as foscarnet, ganciclovir, cidofovir, and famciclovir show efficacy against KSHV replication. The use of antiretroviral therapy in HIV-infected patients helps reduce the viral burden and the frequency of new KS lesions by restoring immune surveillance.

Explanation of other options:

Varicella (Option B): Immunocompromised individuals are at increased risk of severe varicella complications such as disseminated intravascular coagulation, which can be rapidly fatal. In such patients, herpes zoster may also develop, often starting with intense localized pain followed by vesicular eruptions along sensory nerves, with complications like postherpetic neuralgia, pneumonia, and meningitis, sometimes occurring even without a typical rash.

Candida (Option C): Cutaneous candidiasis commonly presents as thrush which is a whitish, patchy to confluent pseudomembranous lesions on the oral mucosa composed of epithelial cells, yeasts, and pseudohyphae. Skin involvement typically affects moist, warm intertriginous areas like the axillae and groin, appearing red, moist, and sometimes vesicular.

Scrofula (Option D): Lymph node tuberculosis typically manifests as non-tender enlargement of lymph nodes, most frequently affecting the posterior cervical and supraclavicular regions, a presentation traditionally known as scrofula.

questions.text: A 15-year-old girl came to the Medicine OPD with complaints of headache, fever, pharyngitis, cervical lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly. A local quack prescribed her an antibiotic, following which she developed rashes. On taking proper history, her doctor also notes that her boyfriend is also suffering from similar symptoms. Which is the most likely cause of this infection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given clinical scenario of pharyngitis, cervical lymphadenopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly along with the development of rash following antibiotic usage supports a diagnosis of infectious mononucleosis caused by EBV.
  • Infectious mononucleosis (IM), primarily caused by Epstein-Barr virus (EBV), often presents asymptomatically or as mild pharyngitis in infants and young children, but in adolescents, about 75% of cases manifest with classic
  • EBV commonly spreads by coming in contact with oral secretions. In young adults, the incubation period is approximately 4–6 weeks, followed by a prodrome of fatigue, malaise, and myalgia for 1–2 weeks before the onset of low-grade fever, pharyngitis, and lymphadenopathy.
  • Lymph node enlargement, especially in the posterior cervical chain, and splenomegaly are common findings, with the former appearing early and the latter during the second and third weeks.
  • The lymph nodes are usually tender, symmetric, and mobile. Pharyngitis, often accompanied by tonsillar enlargement and exudate resembling streptococcal infection, is prominent.
  • A morbilliform or papular rash appears in about 5% of cases, more frequently in those treated with penicillin, and other rashes like erythema nodosum and erythema multiforme may also occur.
  • In elderly patients, IM often presents atypically with prolonged fever, fatigue, malaise, and myalgia, while classic signs like pharyngitis, lymphadenopathy, splenomegaly, and atypical lymphocytes are uncommon.
  • Most symptoms last for 2–4 weeks, though approximately 10% of patients experience fatigue for over 6 months. The severity of disease correlates with elevated CD8+ T cells and EBV DNA levels in blood.
  • In infectious mononucleosis, laboratory findings typically show elevated white blood cell counts peaking between 10,000–20,000/µL by the second or third week, with lymphocytosis featuring over 10% atypical lymphocytes also known as Downey cells.
  • These are seen as large cells with abundant cytoplasm, vacuoles, and membrane indentations as shown below, predominantly CD8+ T cells. The monospot heterophile test is positive in EBV associated infectious mononucleosis.
  • Complications of IM are generally rare but include central nervous system involvement including meningitis, encephalitis, cerebellar ataxia, and cranial nerve palsies. Splenic rupture occurs more commonly in males.
  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia occurs in about 2% of cases, typically Coombs-positive with cold agglutinins, and may be mild or occasionally severe.
  • Other hematologic abnormalities include pancytopenia, red cell aplasia, granulocytopenia, and thrombocytopenia.
  • Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) is linked to various cancers including Burkitt lymphoma, nasopharyngeal carcinoma, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, and gastric carcinoma.

Explanation of other options:

Herpes simplex virus (Option A): Primary HSV-1 infections are often asymptomatic but may cause symptomatic disease in young children (1-5 years), typically affecting the buccal and gingival mucosa. When symptomatic, it presents with fever, sore throat, vesicular or ulcerative lesions, gingivostomatitis (notably gingivitis). Recurrent HSV-1 infections usually manifest as painful clusters of vesicles on the lip border.

Parvovirus (Option C): Human parvovirus B19 most commonly presents in children as erythema infectiosum, marked by fever, mild constitutional symptoms, and a characteristic “slapped cheek” rash that may be followed by a lace-like rash on the limbs or trunk.

Measles virus (Option D): Measles in nonimmune individuals typically begins after an incubation period of 8-15 days with a prodrome marked by fever, cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, Koplik spots, and lymphopenia. The characteristic rash appears 1-2 days after the prodrome, starting on the face and spreading to the trunk and limbs, fading over 5-10 days with desquamation.

questions.text: A 54-year-old retropositive male presents with a rash on his torso as shown below. He was taking immunosuppressants for managing his kidney transplant. What is the most common cause of death in patients affected by the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given scenario is consistent with a diagnosis of herpes zoster in which the most common cause of death is
  • Herpes zoster typically affects individuals with weakened immunity due to illness, aging, or therapy, though it may also appear in healthy young adults.
  • It begins with intense pain in the area supplied by sensory nerves and is soon followed by the appearance of vesicles in the same distribution and is commonly seen on the trunk, head, and neck, with the ophthalmic branch of the trigeminal nerve involved in some cases.
  • The most frequent complication in elderly patients is postherpetic neuralgia, which presents as persistent pain lasting for months, while severe immunosuppressed patients may experience visceral involvement such as pneumonia which is the most common cause of death.
  • CNS complications, like meningitis, may occur with or without typical rash.
  • Varicella , also caused by varicella-zoster virus usually follows an incubation period of 10-21 days and starts with fever and malaise before the rash appears, first on the trunk and then spreading to the face, limbs, and mucosa.
  • The rash consists of crops of macules, papules, vesicles, and crusts, all seen at once, and typically resolves in about five days.
  • Although complications are rare in healthy children, varicella can cause severe outcomes like encephalitis, pneumonia, or disseminated disease in neonates, pregnant women, and immunocompromised individuals such as those with leukemia, organ transplants, HIV, or on corticosteroid therapy.

Explanation of other options:

Secondary bacterial infection (Option A) : Local skin lesions of herpes zoster may get secondarily infected with bacteria (e.g., Staphylococcus aureus, Streptococcus pyogenes).
These infections can cause cellulitis or abscess but are not the leading cause of mortality.

Meningitis (Option B): VZV can cause aseptic meningitis or encephalitis as part of CNS complications. Though serious, these are less frequent causes of death compared to pneumonia.

Myocarditis (Option D): VZV has rarely been associated with myocarditis. It is a very uncommon complication and not a major cause of mortality.

questions.text: A 2-year-old girl presented with diarrhea, vomiting, lethargy, seizures, and weakness. She suffered from chickenpox for 1 week, for which her mother gave her an aspirin tablet for fever. What is the girl suffering from?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario of vomiting, seizures, and lethary along with history of using aspirin in the background of a viral illness suggests a diagnosis of Reye syndrome.
  • Reye syndrome occurs in genetically predisposed individuals following a viral illness, typically influenza or varicella, especially when combined with the use of salicylates or antiemetics. (Options B, C, and D ruled out)
  • It usually presents during the recovery phase of the viral infection with sudden onset of vomiting and signs of brain dysfunction.
  • Neurological manifestations can quickly worsen, potentially progressing to seizures, coma, and even death.
  • Liver involvement is always present at the time of vomiting, with findings such as coagulopathy and increased serum levels of AST, ALT, and ammonia, though patients remain non-jaundiced with normal bilirubin levels.
  • Liver biopsy reveals microvesicular fat accumulation without signs of inflammation or cell death.
  • The most common cause of death is raised intracranial pressure leading to brain herniation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presented with a complaint of dysuria and painful rashes on his penis, as shown below. Examination reveals bilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given clinical features of multiple painful vesicular lesions in the genital area along with bilateral inguinal lymphadenopathy suggests a diagnosis of herpes genitalis caused by herpes simplex virus.
  • Herpes simplex viruses (HSV-1 and HSV-2) are widespread, cytolytic DNA viruses with broad host range and high replication rates. HSV-1 typically spreads via contact with infected saliva, while HSV-2 is mainly transmitted sexually or from mother to newborn, though these patterns can overlap.
  • HSV infects mucosal surfaces or broken skin, then travels via nerves to establish latency in sensory ganglia, with HSV-1 affecting trigeminal and HSV-2 the sacral ganglia.
  • Pathologically, HSV causes necrosis and inflammation in infected cells, with hallmark features like Cowdry type A intranuclear inclusions and giant cell formation.
  • Genital herpes, more commonly due to HSV-2, causes painful vesiculoulcerative lesions in the genital region and may be associated with systemic symptoms and complications like aseptic meningitis.
  • Primary episodes may last up to 3 weeks, while recurrences are usually milder and shorter.
  • Viral shedding during recurrences, even if asymptomatic, enables transmission to sexual partners.

Various features of genital ulcers are summarised in the table below.

Explanation of other options:

Treponema pallidum (Option A): Treponema pallidum causes primary syphilis (chancre) which is a small papule that quickly progresses into a large, non-tender ulcer with a firm, raised edge, typically accompanied by lymph node enlargement on one side

Klebsiella granulomatis (Option C): Klebsiella granulomatis causes donovanosis also known as granuloma inguinale. Donovanosis typically begins as a papule or subcutaneous nodule that ulcerates following trauma. Clinically, it can present in four forms: a friable red ulcer that bleeds easily, a raised wart-like lesion with irregular borders, a foul-smelling necrotic ulcer with tissue destruction or a fibrotic, scar-forming lesion.

Chlamydia serovar L1-3 (Option D): Lymphogranuloma venereum, caused by C. trachomatis serovars L1, L2, and L3, is a systemic sexually transmitted infection. It initially presents as a small, painless papule at the site of entry, which may ulcerate but often goes unnoticed. This primary lesion typically resolves within a few days without leaving a scar and is commonly identified as LGV only after further clinical progression.

choices.text: Give VZIG to the baby after birth

questions.text: A pregnant female at 40 weeks of gestation with expected EDD In 2 days complained that her mother-in-law got chickenpox a week back and now she has developed vesicular lesions and is concerned about her baby. What should be done next?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given clinical scenario puts the baby at risk of perinatal varicella and hence the next best step is to give VZIG to the baby after birth.
  • Perinatal varicella carries a high mortality risk of up to 30% when the mother contracts the infection within five days before or 48 hours after childbirth.
  • The severity in newborns arises from the absence of protective maternal antibodies and their underdeveloped immune systems.
  • In contrast, congenital varicella is rare and presents at birth with features such as limb underdevelopment, scar-like skin lesions, and microcephaly.
  • The three modalities used for prevention of varicella infections are vaccines, varicella zoster immunoglobulin, and antiviral therapy.
  • A live-attenuated vaccine can be given to seronegative individuals above the age of 1 but is contraindicated in pregnancy. (Option A ruled out)
  • An alternative strategy involves giving varicella-zoster immune globulin (VZIG) to susceptible individuals who are at increased risk of severe varicella and have had significant exposure. (Option C ruled out)
  • This should ideally be administered within 72 hours, but it remains effective if given within 96 hours, and possibly up to 10 days after exposure.
  • Newborns are eligible for VZIG if their mother develops varicella within 5 days before or 48 hours after delivery. However, VZIG is not recommended if the mother has herpes zoster.
  • Hospitalized premature infants are also candidates: those born at ≥28 weeks of gestation if the mother lacks evidence of varicella immunity, and those <28 weeks or weighing ≤1000 grams regardless of maternal immune status.
  • Susceptible pregnant women and immunocompromised children without prior varicella infection or vaccination are also recommended to receive VZIG after significant exposure.
  • In addition, antiviral prophylaxis may be used for high-risk individuals who cannot receive the vaccine or are outside the 96-hour window following exposure. (Option B ruled out)
  • The two main clinical entities caused by varicella zoster virus are chickenpox and shingles.
  • In varicella (chickenpox), infection begins via the upper respiratory mucosa or conjunctiva and spreads through primary viremia to the liver and spleen, followed by secondary viremia that brings the virus to the skin.
  • This results in the classic vesicular rash, marked by crops of lesions at different stages such as macules, papules, vesicles, and crusts. They primarily appear on the trunk, face, limbs, and oral mucosa.
  • Herpes zoster (shingles) typically presents in immunocompromised or elderly individuals and begins with localized pain along dermatomal sensory nerves, followed by a vesicular rash in the affected area.
  • Complications include postherpetic neuralgia, especially in older adults, and visceral involvement like pneumonia in the immunosuppressed. Neurological complications such as meningitis may also occur, sometimes even in the absence of rash.

questions.text: An investigator studying the immunologic profile notices that the blood of a test subject agglutinates upon addition of a serum containing antibodies against P blood group antigens. Infection with which of the following pathogens would most likely be prevented by these antibodies?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Antibodies against P blood group antigens would prevent an infection with parvovorius B19 since these viruses bind to the same antigens present on red blood cells.
  • Parvoviruses are the smallest DNA viruses, lacking an envelope and containing single-stranded DNA.
  • They replicate in the nucleus of dividing host cells and require host DNA polymerases due to their inability to initiate DNA synthesis.
  • Human parvovirus B19, the most clinically significant member, targets erythroid progenitor cells, explaining its hematological manifestations. B19 has a strong tropism for red cell precursors, particularly in bone marrow, placenta, and fetal organs, due to its affinity for blood group P antigen.
  • B19 infection causes several clinical syndromes: Erythema infectiosum (fifth disease), typically in children, presents with a characteristic "slapped cheek" facial rash and possible arthropathy, especially in adults.
  • Transient aplastic crisis occurs in individuals with hemolytic anemia, due to abrupt cessation of red blood cell production.
  • Pure red cell aplasia can result from chronic infection in immunocompromised patients and hydrops fetalis can occur due to severe fetal anemia following maternal infection.
  • B19 can be transmitted via respiratory secretions, blood products, and vertically from mother to fetus.
  • Laboratory diagnosis involves PCR detection of viral DNA and serologic testing for IgM and IgG antibodies.

Explanation of other options:

Babesia (Option B): Babesio microti attaches to the red blood cells through C3b complement mediated receptor and is transmitted through ixodes tick bite.

Plasmodium vivax (Option C): Plasmodium vivax targets red blood cells through the duffy antigen.

Epstein-Barr virus (Option D): EBV targets the B lymphocytes.

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 2-day history of low-grade fever and painful lesions on her left index finger. Two weeks ago, she had a painful rash on the right labia majora that resolved without treatment. A photograph of the left index finger is shown. Which organism is responsible for this?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given clinical vignette along with the image showing painful grouped vesicular lesions is suggestive of a herpes simplex virus
  • Herpes simplex viruses (HSV-1 and HSV-2) are widespread human pathogens with a broad host and cell type range, capable of establishing latent infections in nerve cells.
  • HSV-1 is typically transmitted via oral contact and HSV-2 via sexual transmission or vertical maternal spread, though both can cause similar clinical manifestations.
  • Infection begins at mucosal or broken skin sites, followed by transport to sensory ganglia where latency is established.
  • HSV-1 remains latent in the trigeminal ganglia while HSV-2 does so in the sacral ganglia.
  • Primary infections are often asymptomatic or mild, with latency persisting lifelong.
  • Reactivation can occur due to triggers like stress or fever, leading to viral shedding and recurrent lesions.
  • Clinically, HSV causes oropharyngeal disease, keratoconjunctivitis, genital herpes, skin infections, encephalitis, and neonatal herpes, with symptoms ranging from painful vesicular lesions to severe neurologic involvement.
  • Herpetic whitlow is a localized HSV infection of the fingers, commonly affecting healthcare workers or individuals with abrasions that come into contact with infected secretions.Lesions appear as painful, swollen vesicles and are often caused by HSV-1 or HSV-2.
  • Genital herpes, most frequently caused by HSV-2, presents with painful vesiculoulcerative lesions on the genital and perineal areas. Primary infections tend to be severe and prolonged, while recurrences are usually milder and of shorter duration, often with asymptomatic viral shedding that contributes to transmission.
  • Immunocompromised individuals are at risk for severe disease and dissemination.
  • Neonatal HSV can result from vertical transmission, especially during delivery, with high morbidity and mortality. Immunity develops over time, with antibodies appearing after primary infection but not preventing latency or reactivation.
  • Diagnosis involves molecular methods like PCR, viral culture, cytopathology, and serology.
  • Treatment includes antivirals like acyclovir and related agents that inhibit viral DNA synthesis.
  • Preventive strategies involve hygiene, antiviral prophylaxis in certain settings, and condom use. Though experimental vaccines are being developed, none have been successfully implemented yet.

Explanation of other options:

Human papilloma virus (Option B): Human papillomaviruses (HPV) infect both skin and mucosal surfaces, causing a variety of warts such as skin warts, plantar warts, flat warts, anogenital warts, and laryngeal papillomas. They are also linked to several cancers, including cervical, vulvar, penile, anal, and certain head and neck cancers.

Syphilis (Option C): Primary syphilis presents with a papule at the site of inoculation that progresses over 2 to 10 weeks into a painless ulcer with a firm, indurated base, known as a hard chancre.

Staphylococcus aureus (Option D): A localized staphylococcal infection typically presents as a pimple, folliculitis, or abscess, accompanied by a sharply defined, painful area of inflammation. It often progresses to central pus formation and resolves promptly once the purulent material is drained.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man comes to the physician because of a lesion on his penis that has been gradually increasing in size over the past year. He has been divorced for 25 years and has had 'at least 30 sexual partners' since. Physical examination shows a papillary growth in the coronal sulcus of the penis. Which of the following is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Papillomaviruses are non-enveloped, double-stranded circular DNA viruses that replicate within the nucleus and are known for their ability to stimulate host cell DNA synthesis and their interaction with tumor suppressor proteins.
  • These viruses exhibit a restricted host and tissue range and are a major contributor to human cancers, particularly cervical cancer.
  • Classified into over 200 types, papillomaviruses belong to the Papillomaviridae family, with notable genera infecting humans. They show strong tropism for epithelial cells, particularly in skin and mucosal surfaces.
  • Transmission typically occurs through close contact or microabrasions, leading to entry into basal epithelial cells.
  • While early replication occurs in basal stem cells, later viral gene expression is limited to the uppermost differentiated keratinocytes.
  • HPVs cause a variety of clinical manifestations, including common warts, plantar warts, laryngeal papillomas, anogenital warts, and several cancers (cervix, vulva, penis, anus, oropharynx).
  • Types 6 and 11 are low-risk and commonly associated with benign lesions, whereas types 16, 18, and others are high-risk and linked to malignancies, particularly cervical and anal cancers.
  • Condyloma acuminatum is a benign sexually transmitted wart caused by human papillomavirus (HPV), most commonly by low-risk types 6 and 11.
  • These lesions appear on moist surfaces of the external genitalia in both sexes. They are typically seen as single or multiple red, papillary outgrowths that may be sessile or pedunculated, often forming in the coronal sulcus and inner prepuce in males.
  • Persistent infection with high-risk types is crucial for progression to cancer.
  • Vaccination programs using bivalent, quadrivalent, or nonavalent recombinant vaccines targeting high-risk HPV types have significantly contributed to reducing HPV-related cancers and precancerous lesions.

Explanation of other options:

EBV (Option B): Infectious mononucleosis, a classic manifestation of primary Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) infection in adolescents and young adults usually presents with fever, fatigue, malaise, sore throat, and lymphadenopathy. EBV also plays a role in several malignancies including Burkitt lymphoma, nasopharyngeal carcinoma, Hodgkin and non-Hodgkin lymphomas, particularly in immunocompromised individuals and AIDS patients. Genital lesions are not typical.

HSV (Option C): Primary HSV infection typically results in painful clusters of vesicles on red bases, affecting mucocutaneous surfaces such as the lips (HSV-1) or genitalia (HSV-2). These lesions may be associated with fever, malaise, and lymphadenopathy.

Syphilis (Option D): In primary syphilis a papule develops at the site of infection, which subsequently ulcerates to form a firm, clean-based ulcer known as a hard chancre. This lesion is usually painless and represents the hallmark of the primary stage of syphilis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old man presents with a 2-day history of progressively blurred vision. Examination shows right conjunctival injection. Funduscopic examination of the right eye is shown. His CD4+ T-lymphocyte count is 46/mm3. Which of the following is responsible for this patient's eye condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given clinical scenario of blurred vision and given fundoscopy finding of pizza pie appearance in a retropositive patient is suggestive of CMV
  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is a widespread herpesvirus which is a double stranded DNA virus and can cause severe illness in immunocompromised individuals.
  • The virus has a tendency to cause massive enlargement of infected cells with distinctive intranuclear inclusion bodies, leading to the term “cytomegalic inclusion disease.”
  • In normal hosts, CMV is spread through close contact with infected bodily fluids, with a 4–8 week incubation.
  • The infection may cause a mononucleosis-like illness with systemic symptoms or may remain subclinical.
  • CMV establishes lifelong latency and can be shed from the pharynx and in urine for months to years. It may cause prolonged kidney infection without major harm and often involves the salivary glands.
  • Cell-mediated immunity is suppressed during primary infection, contributing to viral persistence and delayed immune recovery.
  • In immunosuppressed individuals, CMV infections are more severe and may lead to pneumonia, hepatitis, colitis, or disseminated disease. These individuals are at risk for reactivation of latent virus, and CMV can cause significant morbidity and mortality.
  • Bone marrow and solid organ transplant recipients are particularly vulnerable, and CMV is a common cause of virus-associated leukopenia and rejection-related complications.
  • In immunocompromised individuals, cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection which is termed “CMV syndrome” typically begins with nonspecific symptoms such as fatigue, fever, general malaise, appetite loss, night sweats, and joint or muscle aches.
  • Respiratory symptoms such as rapid breathing, low oxygen levels, and a dry cough suggest pulmonary disease.
  • CMV can also affect the gastrointestinal tract, particularly in immunocompromised patients, where the involvement can range from localized to widespread. Among organ transplant recipients, colitis is the most frequently encountered manifestation. Additionally, CMV may cause ulcerations in the esophagus, stomach, small bowel, or colon, which can potentially lead to bleeding or perforation.
  • CMV retinitis commonly presents with reduced vision due to macular involvement or floaters from vitritis, initially affecting one eye but progressing to both in about half of untreated cases.
  • Retinitis appears as peripheral dense white retinal infiltrates with flame-shaped hemorrhages leading to a pizza pie appearance, extending along vascular arcades, with granular, non-central lesions being less aggressive (indolent) and central lesions being more fulminant and visually impairing.
  • Congenital CMV infection can lead to developmental delays, or mental retardation. Infection can occur transplacentally, during delivery, or postnatally via breast milk.
  • Infants infected in utero during primary maternal infection are at higher risk of symptomatic disease. While most neonatal infections are subclinical, some are chronic with persistent viral shedding.
  • Intrauterine CMV can lead to serious complications like microcephaly, hepatosplenomegaly, retinitis, periventricular calcification, and sensorineural deafness.
  • CMV causes a mild, mononucleosis-like illness in immunocompetent children and adults.
  • Diagnosis of CMV involves detection of viral DNA by PCR, viral culture in fibroblasts, or serology for IgM and IgG. However, serology is not reliable in immunocompromised patients.
  • Treatment options include ganciclovir (effective against life-threatening infections and progressive hearing loss), foscarnet, and cidofovir for resistant strains.

Explanation of other options:

Syphilis (Option B): Ocular syphilis can manifest as anterior uveitis, which may be granulomatous or non-granulomatous, and is bilateral in half of the cases. Chorioretinitis, often multifocal and bilateral, may be accompanied by vitritis and exudative retinal detachment. Other features include optic neuritis, neuroretinitis, and additional inflammatory or neuro-ophthalmic findings such as Argyll Robertson pupils.

Varicella-zoster virus (Option C): Progressive retinal necrosis (PRN), also referred to as progressive or posterior outer retinal necrosis (PORN), usually caused by varicella-zoster virus presents with rapidly worsening vision, affecting one or both eyes. It is marked by minimal anterior uveitis and vitritis. The condition primarily affects individuals with AIDS or other immunosuppressed states and often results in a poor visual prognosis, with over half of affected eyes losing light perception.

Toxoplasma gondii (Option D): Ocular toxoplasmosis often presents as posterior uveitis, with symptoms including floaters, blurred vision, and photophobia. It is commonly characterized by a solitary focus of fluffy white retinitis adjacent to a pigmented chorioretinal scar, with associated vitritis giving a “headlight in the fog” appearance as shown below.

questions.text: A 7-month-old girl was brought to the physician because of the sudden appearance of a rash on her trunk that started 6 hours ago and subsequently spread to her extremities. Four days ago, she was taken to the emergency department because of a high fever and vomiting. She was treated with acetaminophen and discharged the next day. The fever persisted for several days and abated just prior to appearance of the rash. Physical examination shows a rose coloured, blanching, maculopapular rash, and postauricular lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario of fever in a child which goes down with the appearance of a rsh is suggestive of roseola infantum.
  • Human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6) is the main causative agent of roseola infantum which is an acute, self-limited illness of early childhood characterized by abrupt high fever followed by a faint, pink or rose-colored, non-itchy rash once the fever subsides.
  • The illness usually affects infants around 6–9 months of age, with nearly all children acquiring the infection by age 2 through saliva or respiratory droplets.
  • The fever typically resolves after 72 hours and is often followed by a transient rash beginning on the trunk, sometimes accompanied by mild pharyngeal or conjunctival inflammation and enlarged suboccipital nodes.
  • Seizures, particularly febrile seizures, are the most frequent complication and can occur in up to one-third of affected children, with a higher risk for partial or prolonged seizures in those with HHV-6B infection.
  • Infection can also present with reactivation in immunocompromised individuals, especially post-transplant, leading to serious complications such as encephalitis and posttransplant acute limbic encephalitis (PALE).
  • Although laboratory findings may show decreased white cell counts and atypical lymphocytes, the diagnosis is often clinical unless the presentation is severe or atypical.
  • Treatment is largely supportive, focusing on hydration and antipyretics, while antiviral therapy may be considered for severe or reactivated cases.

Explanation of other options:

Kawasaki disease (Option A): Kawasaki disease presents with persistent high fever and five principal features: bilateral nonexudative conjunctivitis, oral and lip erythema, extremity edema and erythema, polymorphous rash, and unilateral cervical lymphadenopathy. The illness progresses through acute febrile, subacute, and convalescent phases, with the subacute phase posing the greatest risk for coronary complications.

Scarlet fever (Option B): Scarlet fever is a manifestation of GAS pharyngitis characterized by a diffuse, finely papular erythematous rash that typically begins around the neck and spreads to the trunk and limbs within 24-48 hours of symptom onset. The rash is accentuated in skin folds (Pastia lines), gives a rough "goose-pimple" texture, and is followed by desquamation, especially on the face, fingers, palms, and soles. Additional features include erythematous cheeks with circumoral pallor, a coated tongue progressing to a strawberry appearance, and pharyngeal findings similar to GAS pharyngitis.

Non-bullous impetigo (Option D): Nonbullous impetigo is a common superficial skin infection that starts as a discrete papulovesicular lesion with surrounding redness, progressing into purulent vesicles covered by a thick, amber-colored crust. These lesions often occur on the face and extremities and may spread but usually remain mild and chronic if untreated. It is typically not associated with systemic symptoms, though regional lymphadenitis is frequent, and impetiginized lesions around the nares are linked with GAS infections of the nasopharynx in young children.

questions.text: A 49-year-old woman had a routine Pap smear that showed atypical squamous cells. Colposcopy shows an area of white discoloration of the cervix with application of acetic acid solution. Biopsy of this area shows carcinoma-in-situ. Inhibition of which of the following best genes explains the pathogenesis of this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Majority of cervical cancers including cervical carcinoma-in-situ are caused by Human papilloma viruses 16 and 18 which produces E7 protein which inactivates RB gene.
  • High-risk human papillomaviruses (HPVs), especially HPV-16 and HPV-18, are key contributors to cervical cancer, with their DNA frequently integrating into host cell genomes and expressing oncogenic proteins E5, E6, and E7.
  • These proteins disrupt tumor suppressor pathways by degrading p53, inactivating RB, and enhancing telomerase and cell cycle progression, leading to uncontrolled cell proliferation and potential malignant transformation.
  • The E6 protein promotes oncogenesis by targeting the tumor suppressor protein p53 for degradation and enhancing the expression of telomerase reverse transcriptase (TERT), which facilitates cellular immortalization. E6 from high-risk HPV types binds p53 with higher affinity than E6 from low-risk types, explaining the increased cancer risk.
  • The E7 protein complements E6 by accelerating cell cycle progression through the G1/S checkpoint. It binds to the RB protein, displacing E2F transcription factors and promoting cell cycle continuation. E7 from high-risk HPV types has a stronger affinity for RB than E7 from low-risk types, also inactivating CDK inhibitors p21 and p27. Additionally, E7 proteins from high-risk types like HPV 16, 18, and 31 bind and likely activate cyclins A and E.

Explanation of other options:

LMP-1 (Option A): The LMP-1 gene of Epstein-Barr virus (EBV) functions as an oncogene by mimicking an activated CD40 receptor, thereby stimulating B-cell growth without external signals. It activates the NF-κB and JAK/STAT pathways to promote B-cell proliferation and survival and simultaneously inhibits apoptosis by upregulating BCL2 expression.

BRCA (Option C): BRCA1 and BRCA2 are DNA repair genes responsible for correcting double-stranded DNA breaks. Mutations in these genes are linked to familial breast and ovarian cancers, as well as male breast carcinoma.

JAK2 (Option D): JAK2 is an oncogene involved in JAK/STAT signal transduction and is commonly altered through point mutations or translocations. These genetic changes are associated with myeloproliferative disorders and acute lymphoblastic leukemia.

questions.text: A 17-year-old male presents with painful genital sores, malaise, and fever for 3 days. Examination shows tender lymphadenopathy in the left inguinal region and multiple, punched-out ulcers over the penile shaft and glans. Microscopic examination of a smear from the ulcer is most likely to show which of the following?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given clinical vignette is consistent with a diagnosis of herpes genitalis caused by herpes simplex virus -2 which belongs to the family herpes virus which leads to the formation of Cowdry type A intranuclear inclusion bodies.

CMV and measles shows both intranuclear and intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies.

Explanation of other options:

Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells (Option A): Lymphoid tissues infected by the measles virus exhibit follicular hyperplasia with enlarged germinal centers, and contain dispersed multinucleated giant cells known as Warthin-Finkeldey cells.

Owl eye inclusion bodie (Option B): Cytomegalovirus-infected cells undergo significant enlargement and exhibit pleomorphism in both cellular and nuclear morphology. A hallmark feature is the presence of large basophilic intranuclear inclusions that often fill about half of the nucleus, distinctly separated from the nuclear envelope by a clear halo, producing the classic owl eye appearance.

Russell bodies (Option D): In multiple myeloma, Mott cells containing numerous grapelike cytoplasmic droplets are observed, along with other cells that exhibit various inclusions such as fibrils, crystalline rods, and globules. These globular inclusions are termed Russell bodies when located in the cytoplasm and Dutcher bodies when found within the nucleus.

questions.text: A 52-year-old woman comes for a 4-day history of painful swallowing and retrosternal pain. She was diagnosed with HIV infection 2 months ago and her CD4 count is 50/mm3. Endoscopy shows multiple punched-out ulcers in the distal esophagus. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario of dysphagia and retrosternal pain in a retropositive patient with endoscopy showing multiple punched out ulcers is suggestive of Herpes simplex esophagitis.
  • Esophagitis can be categorized into chemical, infectious, reflux, and eosinophilic types, each with distinct causes, features, and histological patterns.
  • Chemical esophagitis arises from irritants like alcohol, corrosive agents, hot fluids, or medications (pill-induced esophagitis), and can result in symptoms ranging from pain on swallowing to hemorrhage or perforation. In children, it often follows ingestion of household cleaners.
  • Iatrogenic injury may occur from chemotherapy, radiation, or graft-versus-host disease (GVHD).
  • Morphologically, chemical injury shows dense neutrophilic infiltrates, although these may be absent in necrotizing chemical injury.
  • Pill-induced forms are typically localized at strictures, while radiation injury leads to intimal thickening, luminal narrowing, and ischemic mucosal injury.
  • Infectious esophagitis commonly affects immunocompromised individuals, caused by herpes simplex virus (HSV), cytomegalovirus (CMV), or fungi.
  • HSV tends to produce punched-out ulcers as shown below with viral inclusions in multinucleated epithelial cells at ulcer margins on biopsy.
  • CMV causes shallower ulcers as shown below with large cells containing both nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusions in endothelial and stromal cells. (Option B ruled out)
  • Fungal infections, especially candidiasis, present with gray-white pseudomembranes as shown below composed of matted fungal hyphae and inflammatory cells over necrotic mucosa. (Option C ruled out)
  • Reflux esophagitis (GERD) results from gastric acid reflux due to lower esophageal sphincter dysfunction. Typical symptoms include heartburn, dysphagia, and regurgitation.
  • Morphologically, mild GERD may show only hyperemia visible on endoscopy, with unremarkable histology. More severe cases exhibit basal cell hyperplasia, papillary elongation, and eosinophilic infiltration. (Option A ruled out)
  • Eosinophilic esophagitis associated with atopy, shows symptoms similar to GERD, including food impaction and vomiting. Endoscopically, the esophagus may appear ringed (feline esophagus) with strictures and furrows. Histologically, it is defined by abundant intraepithelial eosinophils, especially superficial clusters or sheets. These findings help distinguish it from GERD and other causes, though they are not entirely specific.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman comes for an annual pelvic examination and Pap smear. A photomicrograph of cervical cells from the Pap smear specimen is shown. Cells similar to the one indicated by the arrow are most likely to be seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The marked cells in the given pap smear are koilocytes which is considered as a hallmark feature of Human papilloma virus infection which causes condyloma acuminata and various anogenital cancers.
  • Condyloma acuminatum is a benign genital wart primarily caused by low-risk HPV types 6 and 11.
  • It arises on moist mucocutaneous surfaces of the external genitalia in both sexes, commonly affecting the vulva, cervix, perineum, vagina, or perianal area.
  • Clinically, it appears as a soft, exophytic, papillomatous growth.
  • Histologically, the lesion displays branching papillary projections lined by thickened squamous epithelium, with characteristic koilocytosis which is used to describe cells showing enlarged, wrinkled nuclei and a surrounding clear halo.
  • The surface epithelium often demonstrates marked hyperkeratosis. While not premalignant, these warts can recur and are treated using topical therapies or surgical excision.

Explanation of other options:

Genital candidiasis (Option B): Candida species, especially Candida albicans, are frequent components of the normal vaginal microbiota. On Pap smear, the presence of pseudohyphae or filamentous fungal elements, seen as branching forms, supports the diagnosis. These structures can also be visualized using a KOH wet mount preparation.

Bacterial vaginosis (Option C): Gardnerella vaginalis, a gram-negative coccobacillus, is the main organism responsible for bacterial vaginosis. On Pap smear, it is recognized by superficial and intermediate squamous epithelial cells covered with a thick, irregular layer of coccobacilli.

Trichomoniasis (Option D): Trichomonas vaginalis is an ovoid flagellated protozoan that is primarily transmitted through sexual contact. While some infected individuals remain asymptomatic, others may present with yellow, frothy vaginal discharge, vulvovaginal irritation, discomfort during urination, and painful intercourse. On examination, the vaginal mucosa and cervix typically appear bright red with prominent cervical capillaries, producing the classic “strawberry cervix” appearance.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presented with vesicles near the mouth which ruptured and formed an ulcer. A biopsy from the site showed acantholytic cells as shown below. All of the following conditions show acantholytic cells except for?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given image shows acantholytic cells which are seen in blistering skin conditions such as pemphigus vulgaris, pemphigus foliaceous, and also in herpes infections but not in HPV infection.
  • Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection is identified histologically by the presence of koilocytes, which are squamous epithelial cells showing enlarged, irregular, wrinkled nuclei surrounded by a perinuclear clear halo.
  • Acantholysis on the other hand describes the loss of cohesion between squamous epithelial cells and is a key histological feature seen in herpes simplex infections and all forms of pemphigus. (Options A, C, and D ruled out)
  • In herpes simplex virus (HSV) infections, intracellular and intercellular edema along with acantholysis cause clefting that manifests as macroscopic vesicles.
  • These vesicles, filled with serous fluid, rapidly rupture to form painful, shallow ulcers. Microscopy reveals multinucleated giant cells and eosinophilic intranuclear viral inclusions, which can be demonstrated using a Tzanck test.
  • In pemphigus, acantholysis results from the breakdown of intercellular connections between squamous cells. This causes the cells to round up and detach from one another.
  • In pemphigus vulgaris and vegetans, the clefting occurs just above the basal layer, forming suprabasal blisters. The basal cells remain intact and resemble a row of tombstones.
  • In pemphigus foliaceus, the blister formation occurs more superficially, at the level of the stratum granulosum.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents to the OPD with vesicular lesions involving the tip of her nose. On slit lamp examination, the ophthalmologist finds a large corneal abrasion with fluorescein staining and clinical examination also reveals corneal anaesthesia. She gives a history of viral fever with rash during her childhood. Which of the following conditions could be the most likely underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given clinical scenario of vesicular lesions on the nose tip along with corneal anaesthesia and previous history of chickenpox suggests a diagnosis of herpes zoster ophthalmicus.
  • Herpes zoster ophthalmicus (HZO) refers to shingles involving the skin and ocular structures supplied by the ophthalmic division of the fifth cranial (trigeminal) nerve.
  • This condition arises from reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus (VZV), which remains dormant in the sensory ganglia following an earlier episode of chickenpox.
  • Reactivation of VZV causes necrosis and inflammation in the affected sensory ganglia, often resulting in corneal anesthesia and neurotrophic keratopathy.
  • Ocular complications may arise from direct viral invasion, causing conjunctivitis and epithelial keratitis, or from immune-mediated secondary inflammation and occlusive vasculitis. This inflammatory damage may affect multiple ocular structures including the sclera (scleritis), episclera (episcleritis), cornea (keratitis), and uveal tract (uveitis), and can extend to cranial nerves and the central nervous system.
  • Three key risk indicators increase the likelihood of ocular disease:
    • Hutchinson Sign: The presence of vesicles on the tip or side of the nose-innervated by the external nasal branch of the nasociliary nerve, strongly predicts ocular involvement.
    • Age: HZO is more prevalent and severe in individuals in their sixth and seventh decades.
    • AIDS: Immunocompromised individuals are more likely to experience aggressive or recurrent disease.
  • Chronic ocular sequelae include neurotrophic keratopathy, chronic Scleritis and staphyloma.

Explanation of other options:

Nuclear sclerotic cataract (Option A): Nuclear sclerotic cataract represents an age-related enhancement of nuclear lens changes, commonly linked with myopic shift due to increased refractive index, sometimes allowing elderly individuals to read without glasses known as second sight of the aged. It appears yellowish from urochrome pigment deposition and is best visualized with an oblique slit lamp beam.

Sarcoidosis (Option B): Ocular involvement in sarcoidosis is commonly characterized by granulomatous anterior uveitis, trabecular meshwork nodules, and vitreous opacities. Key diagnostic signs include 'mutton fat' keratic precipitates, peripheral chorioretinal lesions with punched-out appearances, and optic disc or choroidal granulomas. Additional features include conjunctival nodules, lacrimal gland infiltration, eyelid nodules, and complications such as cataract, glaucoma, and choroidal neovascularization.

Sjogren syndrome (Option C): In Sjogren’s syndrome, patients commonly report dryness, burning, grittiness, and redness that worsen during the day, often accompanied by stringy discharge and crusting of the eyelids. Corneal signs include punctate epithelial erosions, filaments, and mucous plaques, while complications such as epithelial breakdown, melting, perforation, and bacterial keratitis can be vision-threatening.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male is evaluated in clinic approximately six months after resolution of a herpes zoster. Despite lesions having resolved, he still experiences constant burning and hypersensitivity to touch in the distribution of the old rash. What is the complication?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario of constant burning and pain in the distribution of vesicular rashes which appeared earlier is consistent with a diagnosis of post-herpetic neuralgia.
  • Herpes zoster, also known as shingles, arises from the reactivation of latent varicella-zoster virus (VZV) residing in the dorsal root ganglia.
  • This reactivation occurs most often in immunocompromised individuals due to aging, disease, or therapy, but may also affect healthy adults.
  • The condition begins with severe pain or dysesthesia in the skin or mucosa supplied by one or more sensory nerves, typically in a unilateral distribution.
  • Within a few days, this is followed by the appearance of vesicular eruptions over the corresponding dermatome.
  • Commonly involved regions include the trunk, head, and neck, especially the dermatomes from T3 to L3.
  • A significant and often debilitating complication is postherpetic neuralgia, especially in older adults, which causes persistent pain in the dermatome for months after the rash resolves. Sensory changes such as hypoesthesia or hyperesthesia may also occur.
  • Herpes zoster can also present without cutaneous eruptions, a condition termed zoster sine herpetica, where pain is confined to a dermatome without visible lesions. (Option C ruled out)
  • Ophthalmic involvement, or zoster ophthalmicus, results when the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve is affected, often leading to severe ocular complications including blindness if untreated. (Option B ruled out)
  • A related variant is Ramsay Hunt syndrome as shown below, caused by reactivation of VZV in the geniculate ganglion. It presents with vesicular eruptions in the external auditory canal, loss of taste in the anterior two-thirds of the tongue, and ipsilateral facial nerve palsy. The eighth cranial nerve may also be involved. (Option A ruled out)
  • Neurological complications include meningitis, meningoencephalitis, and transverse myelitis. CSF findings in such patients may show pleocytosis and elevated protein levels.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man comes to the clinic complaining of anal lesions that have been present for a few months. He says that they occasionally itch but are otherwise asymptomatic. Identify the HPV strains responsible for this condition.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given clinical scenario is consistent with a diagnosis of anogenital warts caused by low-risk HPV types 6 and 11.
  • Papillomaviruses infect both the skin and mucous membranes, leading to various types of warts such as skin warts, plantar warts, flat warts, and anogenital warts, as well as laryngeal papillomas.
  • They are also linked to several cancers, including those of the cervix, vulva, penis, anus, and certain head and neck cancers. Different HPV strains tend to be associated with specific clinical lesions, although the correlation is not absolute.
  • The image below shows anogenital warts.
  • The various HPV types and the associated clinical features are summarised in the table below. 

Explanations of other options:

16 and 18 (Option A): Causes cancers of the genital tract, larynx, and esophagus.

1 (Option C): Responsible for plantar warts

2 and 4 (Option D): Associated with common skin warts.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old female suffering from multiple sclerosis presents with complaints of headache, behavioural changes, seizures and ataxia. She was taking the drug Natalizumab for managing MS. An MRI scan was done and image is shown below.
Which family of DNA viruses is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given clinical scenario of white matter lesion in a patient on natalizumab suggests a diagnosis of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy caused by JC virus which belongs to the family Polyomavirus.
  • Progressive Multifocal Leukoencephalopathy (PML) is a rare but serious demyelinating disorder of the central nervous system caused by reactivation of JC virus, typically seen in immunocompromised individuals.
  • Pathologically, it involves multifocal areas of demyelination in the brain, particularly affecting oligodendrocytes and astrocytes, with associated cytologic changes and JC virus inclusions.
  • Common symptoms include visual disturbances, mental status changes, motor weakness, and ataxia, with seizures occurring in a subset of patients.
  • MRI is the key diagnostic tool, often revealing multifocal, asymmetric, nonenhancing lesions in the white matter, while CSF PCR for JC virus confirms the diagnosis.
  • PML is notably associated with AIDS, hematologic malignancies, transplants, chronic inflammatory diseases, and use of certain immunomodulatory therapies like natalizumab.
  • Patients with natalizumab-associated PML may exhibit worsened symptoms following cessation of therapy, attributed to immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS).
  • Prognosis is generally poor, especially in patients with low CD4 counts and high JC viral loads, although survival improves with HAART in HIV-positive individuals. Despite various treatment attempts no consistently effective therapy has been established.
  • Management often focuses on restoring immune function, promptly discontinuing immunosuppressants, and close monitoring for IRIS.

Explanation of other options:

Astrovirus (Option A): Astroviruses cause diarrheal disease and are excreted in large amounts in the stool. Transmission occurs via the fecal-oral route through contaminated food or water, person-to-person contact, or contact with contaminated surfaces. They are particularly recognized as pathogens in infants, children, elderly institutionalized individuals, and immunocompromised patients, and can be shed for prolonged periods in the latter group.

Papillomavirus (Option B): HPV belongs to the Papillomavirus family and can infect both cutaneous and mucosal surfaces, resulting in a range of wart types including skin, plantar, flat, and anogenital warts, along with laryngeal papillomas. They are also implicated in the development of multiple cancers such as cervical, vulvar, penile, anal, and some head and neck malignancies.

Parvovirus (Option D): Parvovirus B19 of the family parvoviridae is linked to several clinical conditions. In children and sometimes adults, it causes erythema infectiosum (fifth disease), which typically presents with a characteristic "slapped-cheek" rash and may be accompanied by joint pain. Individuals with preexisting hemolytic disorders like sickle cell disease may experience a transient aplastic crisis. In immunocompromised individuals, the virus can lead to persistent infections resulting in chronic anemia or pure red cell aplasia. Maternal infection may also transmit the virus to the fetus, potentially causing hydrops fetalis due to fetal anemia.

questions.text: A school going child came presents with the following lesions on body. What are the characteristic inclusion bodies that can be seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The given image shows raised umbilicated papules of molluscum contagiosum which shows Henderson Peterson including bodies.
  • Molluscum contagiosum is a self-limited skin infection caused by a double-stranded DNA poxvirus that replicates in epithelial cells, predominantly affecting children aged 2-6 years and immunocompromised individuals.
  • Transmission typically occurs through direct contact or fomites, with an incubation period of at least two weeks.
  • Lesions appear as discrete, dome-shaped, pearly papules with central umbilication and may occur anywhere on the body, especially on the face, neck, eyelids, axillae, and thighs.
  • In sexually active individuals, lesions may involve the genital area but are usually not sexually transmitted. In AIDS patients and other immunocompromised hosts, lesions are more widespread, especially on the face.
  • Affected children or individuals with atopic dermatitis may experience extensive involvement and develop hundreds of lesions.
  • The papules can show a surrounding eczematous or erythematous base, and pustular eruptions may occur due to an immune reaction, not secondary infection.
  • The disease usually resolves within 6–9 months, though it may persist for years in some cases.
  • Treatment options include immunotherapy with Candida or Trichophyton antigen administered every four weeks. Other therapies for limited lesions include cryotherapy with liquid nitrogen and the application of cantharidin in children, although it should not be used on facial lesions.

Explanation of other options:

Warthin-Finkeldey giant cells (Option A): Seen in measles

Negri bodies (Option B): Associated with rabies infection.

Cowdry B (Option D): Seen in adenovirus and poliovirus.

choices.text: Start empirical treatment for bacterial meningitis
As CSF analysis is normal, symptomatically treat the patient

questions.text: A 5-year male child came with complaints of high-grade fever, seizures and excessive cry. Suspecting meningitis CSF analysis was done, which showed glucose level to be normal and lymphocytic pleocytosis. What should be the next step?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The clinical scenario of lymphocytic pleocytosis and normal glucose levels in the CSF is suggestive of viral meningitis and so the next best step would be to do a CSF PCR analysis to find the etiology.

Explanation of other options:

Repeat CSF analysis (Option A): No indication to repeat CSF analysis.

Start empirical treatment for bacterial meningitis (Option B): Bacterial meningitis constitutes a medical emergency, and treatment should ideally commence within the first hour of the patient’s arrival at the emergency department. Empirical antibiotics are started promptly in suspected cases, even before the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) Gram stain and culture results become available.

As CSF analysis is normal, symptomatically treat the patient (Option C): CSF analysis is not normal since there is lymphocytic pleocytosis.

questions.text: A 6-month post-kidney transplant patient presents with fever, malaise, cough, and diffuse interstitial opacities on chest X-ray. What is the most common diagnostic method to confirm the cause of the infection?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is the most prevalent viral infection following organ transplantation, especially between 1 and 4 months post-transplant and is most commonly confirmed by direct DNA estimation by PCR.
  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV) is the most frequent viral complication after organ transplantation, particularly within the first 1 to 4 months, and poses a serious threat to both patient survival and graft function.
  • The risk is highest in CMV-negative recipients who receive organs from CMV-positive donors. CMV can affect recipients of various organ transplants such as kidney, liver, heart, or lung, due to their immunosuppressed condition, and is associated with systemic illness including fever, leukopenia, hepatitis, pneumonia, retinitis, and gastrointestinal ulcers.
  • In hematopoietic stem cell transplant recipients, particularly those undergoing allogeneic transplants, CMV can cause widespread viremia and life-threatening complications if not addressed promptly.
  • HIV-infected individuals with marked immunosuppression are also vulnerable, especially to retinitis.
  • The clinical presentation of CMV syndrome includes general symptoms, blood cell deficiencies, and hepatic involvement, which may evolve into multiorgan dysfunction if untreated.
  • Among gastrointestinal manifestations, CMV colitis is the most frequent in transplant recipients, and its diagnosis may require tissue confirmation when blood tests fail to detect viral markers.
  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection typically cannot be diagnosed based solely on clinical signs. The preferred diagnostic methods involve detecting CMV DNA or antigens in relevant clinical specimens, with quantitative nucleic acid testing (QNAT) using PCR being the most widely used. (Options B, C, and D ruled out)
  • Some labs also employ CMV antigenemia assays that detect pp65 antigens in peripheral blood leukocytes, which can yield earlier results than cultures. QNAT is particularly valuable in immunocompromised individuals for assessing disease progression risk.
  • Detection of CMV DNA in cerebrospinal fluid aids in diagnosing CMV encephalitis or polyradiculopathy. To minimize test result variability, international standards for viral load testing have been implemented.
  • Virus culture using human fibroblast monolayers is another diagnostic method, especially effective when viral loads are high, as seen in congenital CMV and AIDS. Cytopathic effects can appear within days, although they may take weeks in low-titer cases like CMV mononucleosis.
  • Rapid diagnostic methods include overnight shell vial assays with immunocytochemical staining for immediate-early CMV antigens. Isolation from urine, stool, or saliva alone is not definitive since shedding may persist long after illness.
  • Serologic testing for CMV antibodies is also available. IgG antibodies may take weeks to rise post-infection, and although CMV-specific IgM can help identify recent infections, false positives may occur due to factors like rheumatoid disease.

questions.text: A newly born child presented with the following features. What could be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Explanation :

  • The given image shows limb hypoplasia and cicatricial scars in the baby suggestive of congenital varicella.
  • Congenital varicella syndrome results from maternal infection with varicella-zoster virus during early pregnancy, especially when the primary infection occurs in the first or early second trimester.
  • Key clinical features include scar-like skin lesions, limb underdevelopment, central nervous system abnormalities such as microcephaly, mental retardation, and seizures, along with ocular issues like chorioretinitis, microphthalmia, and cataracts.
  • Renal anomalies like hydroureter and hydronephrosis, neurogenic bladder, and low birth weight are also associated with the syndrome.

Explanation of other options:

Congenital CMV infection (Option A): Congenital CMV infection is symptomatic in only 10% and usually presents with features such as hepatosplenomegaly, petechiae, jaundice, microcephaly, and growth restriction. Long-term consequences, especially hearing loss, can develop even after an initially normal hearing screen, necessitating regular follow-up. Additional complications may include chorioretinitis, CNS damage, and motor deficits.

Neonatal varicella syndrome (Option B): Neonatal varicella is a severe form of chickenpox that can occur in newborns if the mother develops chickenpox from 5 days before to 2 days after delivery, a period during which protective maternal antibodies have not yet formed. This leads to viral dissemination in the infant, with a mortality rate exceeding 30%. In contrast, if maternal infection occurs more than 5 days prior to delivery, the baby is generally asymptomatic due to the passive transfer of maternal antibodies, which prevent transmission during birth.

Fetal alcohol syndrome (Option D): Fetal alcohol syndrome is a teratogenic condition caused by ethanol toxicity to the developing brain. It is characterized by microcephaly, developmental delay, distinct facial anomalies as shown below, and behavioral abnormalities.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child got infected with a dsDNA virus which caused high grade fever and maculopapular rash. Rash which appears in crops started on the 1st day of fever and later spread centrifugally sparing palms and soles. What is the second most common infectious complication of the above condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The most likely diagnosis based on the given scenario of rash which appears in crops on the first day of fever which later spreads centrifugally is chickenpox and the second most common infectious complication of chickenpox is meningoencephalitis.
  • Chickenpox typically presents with a prodrome of low-grade fever, malaise, and a characteristic rash consisting of maculopapules, vesicles, and scabs in different stages.
  • These lesions begin on the trunk and face and spread across the body, including mucosal areas such as the pharynx and vagina.
  • Younger children generally have fewer vesicles than older individuals, and disease severity is variable. Immunocompromised patients tend to have more severe, hemorrhagic lesions and a higher risk of visceral involvement.
  • The most common infectious complication is secondary bacterial skin infection, commonly caused by Streptococcus pyogenes or Staphylococcus aureus, including methicillin-resistant strains. This usually results from scratching. (Option B ruled out)
  • The central nervous system is the most frequently affected extracutaneous site, with complications like acute cerebellar ataxia, encephalitis, aseptic meningitis, and Guillain-Barré syndrome.
  • Varicella pneumonia is the most serious complication, especially in adults and pregnant women, and manifests with respiratory symptoms and characteristic radiologic findings. (Option C ruled out)
  • Other reported complications include myocarditis, corneal lesions, nephritis, arthritis, bleeding disorders, acute glomerulonephritis, and hepatitis. Hepatic involvement is often asymptomatic but shows elevated liver enzymes. Use of aspirin in children with chickenpox may lead to Reye’s syndrome, which is why it is now avoided. (Option A ruled out)
